title: Greubel Forsey Updates Tourbillon 30° Technique With Ceramic and Sapphire Crystal
text:
Text size

Greubel Forsey has introduced a new edition of its signature Double Tourbillon 30° Technique, offering a showcase of the movement’s extravagant architecture.

Limited to 11 pieces, the Double Tourbillon 30° Technique in ceramic ($695,000) is exclusive to the U.S. market and the first watch the brand has ever produced with a ceramic case.

Transparency and light play were the driving forces in reconfiguring the piece, with its eye-catching 48.40mm blue ceramic case serving as the colorful frame for the mechanical art within. The Double Tourbillon 30° movement, which launched the brand in 2004, has been reinterpreted with translucent sapphire crystal, which is extremely hard and challenging to machine.

In reconstructing the movement, Robert Greubel and Stephen Forsey embraced that challenge as a means to heighten the visual impact of the mechanism. Particularly daunting were the three-dimensional sapphire bridges machined from single blocks of sapphire crystal with flanks polished using different finishes, a process that required special tools and exceptional expertise.

The beveled angles have a matte finish to create a contrast with the polished surfaces, while the clear bridges provide a window into the mesmerizing movement’s layers of wheels and pinions.

Taking the transparent concept to its extreme, the tourbillon bridge, barrel bridge, differential bridge, and power-reserve bridge were removed and recreated in sapphire in order to fully reveal the watch’s inner workings. Even tiny details such as screws were re-evaluated, and the bridges had to be specially mounted for heightened shock absorption.

The hour and minute ring, as well as the four-minute tourbillon-rotation indicator at 6 o’clock are also made from clear sapphire crystal to allow light to flow through the mechanism, while the hands have been skeletonized to amplify the piece’s ethereal character.

It's the first watch the brand has ever produced with a ceramic case. Greubel Forsey

The eye is immediately drawn to the whirling Double Tourbillon 30° mechanism with two suspended cages pirouetting at different speeds. The outer cage completes a revolution in four minutes while the inner smaller cage, containing the balance and spring assembly, completes its rotation in one minute, while inclined at a 30° angle relative to the first cage.

That 30° inclination combined with the different rotational speeds of the two tourbillons, delivers heightened precision by averaging out positional errors due to gravity. Meanwhile, four coaxial barrels coupled to a spherical power-reserve differential, provide a chronometric power reserve of 120 hours.

Heightened performance is not merely theoretical at Greubel Forsey. Seven years after the partners unveiled the Double Tourbillon 30° Technique, it took first prize at the Concours International de Chronométrie, with an average timing rate of between 0.3 and 0.8 seconds per day over the entire course of the competition.

From the case back side, the unusually large, multilevel gear train bridge reveals the finely finished movement structure beneath. The lower tourbillon bridge is also sapphire made to exactly mimic the steel bridge of the original Double Tourbillon 30° Technique, which was no small feat working with such an extremely hard material.

Another first for the brand is the colored case made of ceramic, sintered at very high temperatures to endow it with extreme resistance to scratches and corrosion. The toughness of that material makes it more difficult to finish—from polishing to linear or circular satin finishing that impart a subtle shimmer, complementing the radiant sapphire movement.

The special U.S. edition is fitted with a ceramic crown featuring a tone-on-tone engraved Greubel Forsey logo, and it comes on a blue rubber strap with the company’s guiding principles spelled out on the interior.
description: Limited to 11 pieces, the watch will sell for $695,000 only in the U.S. market
